questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Jhumpa Lahiri’s 2003 novel The Namesake. Gogol is an elementary school student in Massachusetts.

In art class, his favorite hour of the week, he carves his name with paper clips into the bottoms of clay cups and bowls. He pastes uncooked pasta to cardboard, and leaves his signature in fat brush strokes below paintings.

©2003 by Jhumpa Lahiri
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “leaves” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Writes

options.name: B
options.content: Switches

options.name: C
options.content: Allows

options.name: D
options.content: Promotes

questions.correct: Writes

questions.article: City planners need accurate maps of their city’s sidewalks to properly maintain them, but mapping manually is slow. Maryam Hosseini and her team addressed this by training a computer program to identify sidewalks in aerial images of Manhattan. When they used the program on aerial images of Brooklyn, it accurately ______ sidewalks and could even distinguish between concrete and cobblestone.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: approved

options.name: B
options.content: neglected

options.name: C
options.content: mistook

options.name: D
options.content: detected

questions.correct: detected

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from John Matheus’s 1925 short story “Fog.”

The fog extended its tentacles over city and river, gradually obliterating traces of familiar landscapes. At five-thirty the old Panhandle bridge, supported by massive sandstone pillars, stalwart, as when erected fifty years before to serve a generation now passed behind the portals of life, had become a spectral outline against the sky.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word "supported" most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Nurtured

options.name: B
options.content: Endorsed

options.name: C
options.content: Held up

options.name: D
options.content: Improved on

questions.correct: Held up

questions.article: The Mexican Revolution (1910–1920) was followed by a period of flourishing literary production, with writers such as Laura Esquivel contributing to the ______ of poetry, fiction, essays, and more. Unfortunately, this flood of interesting writing has diverted scholarly attention from the equally fascinating work of nineteenth-century figures like Antonio Menendez de la Peña.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: outpouring

options.name: B
options.content: overturning

options.name: C
options.content: censure

options.name: D
options.content: protection

questions.correct: outpouring

questions.article: In 1867, Jennie Carter began her journalism career by writing children’s stories for the San Francisco newspaper The Elevator. Carter’s accomplishment is just one example of the rich history of Black journalism in the United States. That history is preserved by the National Association of Black Journalists, which was founded in Washington, DC, in 1975 to support Black media professionals and honor people like Carter.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It summarizes a theory about journalism, then explains how a journalistic practice has changed over time.

options.name: B
options.content: It mentions a specific achievement in Black journalistic history, then describes an organization dedicated to upholding that history.

options.name: C
options.content: It introduces the history of an organization honoring Black journalists, then suggests how that organization might recruit more members.

options.name: D
options.content: It describes the career of a well-known figure in Black journalism, then compares that career to one of a figure who is lesser known.

questions.correct: It mentions a specific achievement in Black journalistic history, then describes an organization dedicated to upholding that history.

questions.article: Community science, which involves professional scientists collaborating with amateur science enthusiasts to study a topic, is often an effective and engaging way to conduct research. It can allow people to assist with conservation efforts, build youth confidence in the sciences, and increase the amount of data researchers can collect. This approach was essential to the success of a study by biologist Abbigail Merrill and colleagues of how butterfly color relates to flower choice, which included findings from hundreds of students and community members in northwestern Arkansas.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It identifies a particular approach to research, lists some benefits of that approach, and then mentions a study in which that approach was used.

options.name: B
options.content: It argues for a new approach to scientific research, comments on the public’s opinion about the approach, and then describes how that approach was applied in a certain study.

options.name: C
options.content: It describes the development of a type of scientific collaboration, shows how that type of collaboration has been used in a particular field of study, and then suggests future collaborative projects.

options.name: D
options.content: It introduces the topic of a scientific study, describes the study’s importance, and then presents the study’s results.

questions.correct: It identifies a particular approach to research, lists some benefits of that approach, and then mentions a study in which that approach was used.

questions.article: Yingguang Frank Chan and colleagues have explored how convergent evolution—a phenomenon that occurs when the same trait evolves independently in two reproductively separate lineages—can result from a genetic mechanism shared by both lineages. Meanwhile, Bas J. Zwaan and colleagues have investigated how convergence occurs through different genetic mechanisms, but the relative prevalence of convergence through shared and different genetic processes is still poorly understood. This motivated biologists Delbert A. Green II and Cassandra G. Extavour to evaluate both types of convergence in a single study for their 2012 paper.
questions.question: Which choice best states the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It details the development of a field of scientific inquiry, gives examples of three studies that were important to this development, and speculates on how future studies can develop these ideas.

options.name: B
options.content: It explains a widespread assumption about a phenomenon, describes two studies that are based on that assumption, and explains why the assumption is unfounded.

options.name: C
options.content: It discusses a particular study of a phenomenon, elaborates on how two other studies have approached this phenomenon in the past, and critiques the first study’s approach.

options.name: D
options.content: It describes a phenomenon, provides examples of two studies of that phenomenon, and mentions a third study of that phenomenon.

questions.correct: It describes a phenomenon, provides examples of two studies of that phenomenon, and mentions a third study of that phenomenon.

questions.article:
The following text is from John Manuel Arias’s 2023 novel Where There Was Fire. Teresa lives in Barrio Ávila, a neighborhood in a Costa Rican city.

Observant clouds gathered over Barrio Ávila. Teresa sat up in her bed, startled by a flashing news report on television. She wasn’t sure when she’d fallen asleep. Four in the morning, maybe. On most nights, sleep came quickly to her. Violently. But last night, Teresa felt as if she had waded into it slowly, almost willingly. As one does when playful moonlight splashes in the receding tide and invites you to join it.

©2023 by John Manuel Arias
questions.question: What is the main topic of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: How Teresa has awakened and how she fell asleep earlier

options.name: B
options.content: Why Teresa only watches television news before going to bed

options.name: C
options.content: How Teresa is enjoying the change in the weather

options.name: D
options.content: What Teresa expects to do the following day

questions.correct: How Teresa has awakened and how she fell asleep earlier

questions.article: Companies involved in petroleum refining include inventory of petroleum products among their assets. But petroleum refining is a very carbon-intensive industry, so as renewable energy becomes more economically competitive, demand for petroleum falls and the inventory of petroleum products will eventually, or even suddenly, become a liability as the cost of producing petroleum products exceeds what people will pay for them.
questions.question: What claim does the text make about the demand for petroleum?

options.name: A
options.content: The demand for petroleum follows a predictable annual cycle.

options.name: B
options.content: The competition from renewable energy is a factor in the demand for petroleum.

options.name: C
options.content: Companies involved in petroleum refining are not affected by the demand for petroleum.

options.name: D
options.content: Companies involved in petroleum refining can benefit from a decline in the demand for petroleum.

questions.correct: The competition from renewable energy is a factor in the demand for petroleum.

questions.article:
The following text is from Julia Alvarez’s 2000 novel In the Name of Salomé. The narrator and her sister, daughters of a famous poet, are being tutored by Alejandro Román.

Our tutor, Alejandro Román, brought his younger brother, Miguel, to class one day. By now I was eighteen and had learned everything Alejandro had to teach me, so I was glad for a new face. Miguel was an aspiring poet, and he had heard from his brother that the Ureña girls were none other than the daughters of Nicolás Ureña, and they were smart as clockwork. Miguel was hoping not only to meet us but to make the acquaintance of the poet himself at Mamá’s house.

©2000 by Julia Alvarez
questions.question: Based on the text, why does Miguel accompany his brother to the sisters’ house one day?

options.name: A
options.content: Miguel has not received formal instruction in poetry and wants to ask the sisters’ famous father to be his mentor.

options.name: B
options.content: Miguel has learned all his brother can teach him and now desires to be taught by the sisters.

options.name: C
options.content: Miguel hopes to recite his own poetry to the sisters and solicit their comments on his work.

options.name: D
options.content: Miguel anticipates having the opportunity to be introduced to both the sisters and their father.

questions.correct: Miguel anticipates having the opportunity to be introduced to both the sisters and their father.

questions.article: Terrestrial plants typically carry a negative electrical charge, while hummingbirds and other pollinators tend to accumulate a positive charge. A team of researchers therefore hypothesized that electrostatic attraction (mutual attraction between objects with opposite charges) might enhance pollen transmission between plants and their pollinator species. The team’s experiments showed that the maximum positive charge of European peacock butterflies is sufficiently high to facilitate electrostatic pollen transfer, a finding that suggests that ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the text?

options.name: A
options.content: common wasps should demonstrate the opposite tendency.

options.name: B
options.content: the minimum positive charge necessary for a pollinator to induce electrostatic attraction must be greater than 200 pC.

options.name: C
options.content: Anna’s hummingbirds should also demonstrate this capacity.

options.name: D
options.content: Anna’s hummingbirds and common wasps, having greater maximum charges than European peacock butterflies have, should not demonstrate this capacity.

questions.correct: Anna’s hummingbirds should also demonstrate this capacity.

questions.article: Southwestern Nevada’s Esmeralda County is among the most rural counties in the United States: the US Census Bureau classified it as 100% rural in 2010. Researchers have struggled to recruit residents of counties like Esmeralda for inclusion in studies. Noting this problem, Melissa Valerio and colleagues tested two recruitment techniques in rural counties: purposive sampling, in which researchers contact many potential participants who have the characteristics desired for a given study, and snowball sampling, in which researchers recruit a few people with the desired characteristics and ask them to recruit additional participants. Valerio and colleagues concluded that the latter approach may be superior.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Valerio and colleagues’ conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Most participants recruited through snowball sampling had different characteristics than the initial participants who recruited them.

options.name: B
options.content: Participants recruited through snowball sampling were more likely to have taken part in previous studies than were participants recruited through purposive sampling.

options.name: C
options.content: Snowball sampling yielded significantly more participants with the desired characteristics than purposive sampling did.

options.name: D
options.content: Snowball sampling yielded significantly more participants than would be expected if researchers contacted people without regard to those people’s characteristics.

questions.correct: Snowball sampling yielded significantly more participants with the desired characteristics than purposive sampling did.

questions.article: While US public charities, like Habitat for Humanity International, must file Form 990 yearly with the IRS, private foundations, such as Lilly Endowment Inc., must file a different form, 990-PF. In addition, foundations that engage in certain prohibited activities must also file Form 4720 and pay a penalty tax on the money involved. Private foundations are prohibited from holding excess interests in a business enterprise, “self-dealing” (conducting activities that benefit foundation insiders), making taxable expenditures such as grants to noncharitable entities, and failing to cross a required threshold in making charitable distributions from income. Out of the organizations that filed Form 990-PF in the years 2003–2005, ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the assertion?

options.name: A
options.content: those that filed Form 4720 in 2005 because they engaged in self-dealing collectively paid a larger percentage of the total penalty assessed that year than those that filed Form 990 but also filed Form 4720 for the same reason.

options.name: B
options.content: those that filed Form 4720 because they had excess holdings in a business enterprise paid, on average, a larger penalty than those that filed Form 4720 because they engaged in self-dealing.

options.name: C
options.content: those that filed Form 4720 because they engaged in self-dealing paid an increasing percentage of the total penalty each year from 2003 to 2005.

options.name: D
options.content: those that filed Form 4720 in 2003 because they failed to meet the minimum charitable distribution requirement collectively paid a larger percentage of the total penalty assessed that year than those that filed Form 4720 in 2005 for the same reason.

questions.correct: those that filed Form 4720 in 2003 because they failed to meet the minimum charitable distribution requirement collectively paid a larger percentage of the total penalty assessed that year than those that filed Form 4720 in 2005 for the same reason.

questions.article: Humans have a very strong bias toward right-handedness, with approximately 85–90% having right as their dominant hand. Among studies of nonhuman primates, Mara Aruguete and colleagues’ 1992 study of captive chimpanzees and squirrel monkeys reported more right-handed individuals than left-handed ones, but Lesley J. Rogers and Gisela Kaplan’s 1995 study of wild orangutans did not find a tendency toward right-handedness. It’s important to note, however, that captive animals spend significantly more time with humans than wild animals do, and therefore ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: the number of individuals in the study of wild orangutans is probably too small to support the claim that no tendency toward right-handedness was found in that population.

options.name: B
options.content: the apparent difference between the two studies’ results may be partly attributable to the 1992 study using a different standard to determine handedness than the 1995 study did.

options.name: C
options.content: the right-handedness exhibited by the captive chimpanzees and squirrel monkeys might be, in part, an effect of extended contact with humans.

options.name: D
options.content: the number of individuals in the study of captive chimpanzees and squirrel monkeys is likely too small to support the claim that the species tends toward right-handedness.

questions.correct: the right-handedness exhibited by the captive chimpanzees and squirrel monkeys might be, in part, an effect of extended contact with humans.

questions.article: In May of 1986, the Philippines liberalized its stock market, meaning that it began allowing foreign individuals and businesses to invest money in Filipino companies. This was part of a wave of stock market liberalizations around the world—Malaysia in 1987, Morocco in 1988, and so on. The standard view among economists at the time was that liberalization would make it easier for companies to raise money from investors. Economist Peter Blair Henry examined the economies of 11 countries that were part of the liberalization wave and found that, on average, companies based in those countries received significant increases in investment in the three years following liberalization, suggesting that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: empirical evidence was consistent with the scholarly consensus about the consequences of liberalization.

options.name: B
options.content: economists who held the standard view of liberalization failed to anticipate some serious negative effects of liberalization.

options.name: C
options.content: companies did not benefit from liberalization until at least three years after liberalization occurred.

options.name: D
options.content: companies in Malaysia experienced a greater increase in investment following liberalization than did companies in the Philippines.

questions.correct: empirical evidence was consistent with the scholarly consensus about the consequences of liberalization.

questions.article: From Lyon, France, to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, the International Criminal Police Organization (Interpol) ______ offices in more than 200 cities around the world.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: to oversee

options.name: B
options.content: oversees

options.name: C
options.content: overseeing

options.name: D
options.content: having overseen

questions.correct: oversees

questions.article: As comet 3D/Biela orbits the Sun, it sheds icy fragments that gradually spread out along the comet’s orbit, forming the Andromedid meteoroid stream. Although ______ particles range in size from specks of dust to larger rocks, the Andromedid stream—like other meteoroid streams—has far more small fragments than large ones.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: their

options.name: B
options.content: they’re

options.name: C
options.content: it’s

options.name: D
options.content: its

questions.correct: its

questions.article: Inspired by her Penobscot heritage, artist Sarah Sockbeson typically uses sweetgrass—a fragrant and flexible ______ craft baskets that are both beautiful and whimsical.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: material; to

options.name: B
options.content: material: to

options.name: C
options.content: material. To

options.name: D
options.content: material—to

questions.correct: material—to

questions.article: The programming language ______ for teaching programming skills—was released in 1970.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Pascal—created by Niklaus Wirth

options.name: B
options.content: Pascal, created by Niklaus Wirth,

options.name: C
options.content: Pascal created by Niklaus Wirth

options.name: D
options.content: Pascal, created by Niklaus Wirth

questions.correct: Pascal—created by Niklaus Wirth

questions.article: In their 2021 study of moon jellyfish (Aurelia aurita), ______ found that the jellyfish propel themselves forward with minimal exertion by generating powerful water vortexes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: US biologist, Brad Gemmell, and colleagues

options.name: B
options.content: US biologist Brad Gemmell and colleagues

options.name: C
options.content: US biologist, Brad Gemmell, and colleagues,

options.name: D
options.content: US biologist Brad Gemmell, and colleagues

questions.correct: US biologist Brad Gemmell and colleagues

questions.article: Two siblings from the same biological parents can inherit different physical traits. For instance, one sibling might inherit brown eyes; the other sibling, ______ might inherit green eyes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: for example,

options.name: B
options.content: with this in mind,

options.name: C
options.content: lastly,

options.name: D
options.content: by contrast,

questions.correct: by contrast,

questions.article: On July 12, 1979, Peru’s government lowered the minimum voting age for its citizens from 21 to 18 years old. ______ many young people in Peru gained a new opportunity to participate in their country’s political process.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Similarly,

options.name: B
options.content: By contrast,

options.name: C
options.content: Consequently,

options.name: D
options.content: Nevertheless,

questions.correct: Consequently,

questions.article: In 2015, geologist Peter Rogerson calculated that the geographic center of Indiana was a point 10.8 miles northwest of the municipality of Indianapolis. Rogerson’s calculation was more accurate than the one from 1920 by the US Geological Survey. ______ this earlier calculation was made using far more rudimentary equipment—only cardboard and string.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Likewise,

options.name: B
options.content: To that end,

options.name: C
options.content: Of course,

options.name: D
options.content: Ultimately,

questions.correct: Of course,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Japanese Ministry of the Environment made a list of 100 soundscapes of Japan.
  • Each soundscape on the list was selected for its cultural significance to Japan.
  • The sound of cicadas at the Yama-dera temple is on the list.
  • The sound of birds at the Higashiyama Botanical Garden is on the list.
questions.question: The student wants to indicate that both soundscapes are on the list. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Japanese Ministry of the Environment made a list of 100 culturally significant soundscapes of Japan.

options.name: B
options.content: The sound of birds at the Higashiyama Botanical Garden is on the list.

options.name: C
options.content: Both the sound of cicadas at the Yama-dera temple and the sound of birds at the Higashiyama Botanical Garden are on the list.

options.name: D
options.content: Each soundscape on the list, including the sound of cicadas at the Yama-dera temple, was selected for its cultural significance to Japan.

questions.correct: Both the sound of cicadas at the Yama-dera temple and the sound of birds at the Higashiyama Botanical Garden are on the list.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Many disused railroad corridors in the US have been converted into public trails since the 1960s.
  • Such trails are known as rail trails.
  • The George S. Mickelson Trail is a rail trail located in South Dakota.
  • It is 109 miles long and is made of crushed stone.
  • The Cannon Valley Trail is a rail trail located in Minnesota.
  • It is 19.7 miles long and is made of asphalt.
questions.question: The student wants to compare the lengths of the two rail trails. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Similar to the Cannon Valley Trail, the 109-mile-long George S. Mickelson Trail was created from a disused railroad corridor.

options.name: B
options.content: Although they are made of different materials, the George S. Mickelson Trail and the Cannon Valley Trail are nearly identical in length.

options.name: C
options.content: Rail trails of different lengths can be found in South Dakota and Minnesota.

options.name: D
options.content: At 109 miles long, the George S. Mickelson Trail is much longer than the 19.7-mile Cannon Valley Trail.

questions.correct: At 109 miles long, the George S. Mickelson Trail is much longer than the 19.7-mile Cannon Valley Trail.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • A ship’s carrying capacity is also known as its deadweight tonnage (DWT).
  • In 2021, a total of 2,137 merchant ships were registered in Malta.
  • The average DWT of these ships was 54,000 tons per ship.
  • In 2021, a total of 429 merchant ships were registered in Taiwan.
  • The average DWT of these ships was 17,000 tons per ship.
  • The average DWT among all merchant ships globally was 21,389 tons per ship.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize the deadweight tonnage of merchant ships in Malta in 2021. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In 2021, Malta’s merchant ships had an average deadweight tonnage of 54,000 tons, higher than the global average of 21,389 tons.

options.name: B
options.content: Taiwan had 429 merchant ships in 2021, while Malta had 2,137.

options.name: C
options.content: In 2021, Taiwan’s 429 merchant ships had an average deadweight tonnage of 17,000 tons.

options.name: D
options.content: The average carrying capacity, or deadweight tonnage, of merchant ships in Taiwan was 17,000 tons in 2021.

questions.correct: In 2021, Malta’s merchant ships had an average deadweight tonnage of 54,000 tons, higher than the global average of 21,389 tons.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Dinosaur fossil specimens can be found at science museums all over the world.
  • Many dinosaur fossil specimens are given nicknames.
  • The New Mexico Museum of Natural History in Albuquerque, New Mexico, houses a dinosaur fossil specimen nicknamed Spike.
  • Spike lived in the Late Cretaceous period, which ended more than 65 million years ago.
  • It is a member of the genus Pentaceratops.
questions.question: The student wants to provide an example of a dinosaur fossil specimen’s nickname. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: A Pentaceratops fossil specimen from the Late Cretaceous period, which ended more than 65 million years ago, is housed at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History.

options.name: B
options.content: Dinosaur fossil specimens can be found at museums all over the world, and many of these specimens are given nicknames.

options.name: C
options.content: Nicknames are given to many dinosaur fossil specimens, including one housed at a museum in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

options.name: D
options.content: Spike is the nickname of a Pentaceratops fossil specimen housed at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

questions.correct: Spike is the nickname of a Pentaceratops fossil specimen housed at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History in Albuquerque, New Mexico.
